title: The science of milk - Jonathan J. O'Sullivan

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when milk is exposed to high heat to kill microbes and extend shelf life?

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: What’s so great about the Great Lakes? - Cheri Dobbs and Jennifer Gabrys

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the Great Lakes?

options.label: A
options.text: They are the largest area of saltwater lakes in the world.

options.label: B
options.text: They are the largest area of freshwater lakes in the world.

options.label: C
options.text: They are the only lakes in the world that border eight states.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the only lakes in the world that contain 23 quadrillion liters of water.

multiple-choice.question: How did the Great Lakes come to be?

options.label: A
options.text: They were formed by volcanic activity.

options.label: B
options.text: They were formed by the movement of tectonic plates.

options.label: C
options.text: They were formed by the slow retreat of glaciers over 10,000 years ago.

options.label: D
options.text: They were formed by the erosion of the Earth's surface.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about Lake Superior?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the warmest of the Great Lakes.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the shallowest of the Great Lakes.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the deepest, coldest, and clearest of the Great Lakes, containing half the system's water.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the smallest of the Great Lakes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the average time a drop of water spends in Lake Superior before flowing into another lake?
What is the status of Lake Erie?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the largest of the Great Lakes.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the warmest and shallowest of the Great Lakes.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the deepest of the Great Lakes.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the smallest of the Great Lakes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of human activities on the Great Lakes?

options.label: A
options.text: They have improved the water quality and reduced pollution.

options.label: B
options.text: They have had no impact on the Great Lakes.

options.label: C
options.text: They have degraded the coastal habitats and introduced invasive species.

options.label: D
options.text: They have increased the water levels and changed the distribution of aquatic life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the Great Lakes?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide natural water filtration and flood control.

options.label: B
options.text: They provide only drinking water for people.

options.label: D
options.text: They provide none of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effort needed to protect the Great Lakes?

options.label: C
options.text: Collaboration between many organizations is needed.

What is the intelligence that involves the ability to teach and communicate knowledge to others?

title: How to master your sense of smell - Alexandra Horowitz

multiple-choice.question: What can perfumers learn to distinguish in a fragrance made of hundreds of scents?

options.label: A
options.text: The location where the fragrance was made.

options.label: B
options.text: The season of the year when the fragrance was created.

multiple-choice.question: Who has been known to sniff out not just the location where a tea was from, but the season of harvest and whether it was planted by a plum tree?
What is the main reason why most people may be missing opportunities to make strong emotional connections through smells?

options.label: A
options.text: They lack the ability to smell well.

options.label: B
options.text: They don't pay close enough attention to their surroundings.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not interested in smells.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not aware of the connection between smells and emotions.

multiple-choice.question: How can people train their brains to smell better?

options.label: A
options.text: By paying close attention to their surroundings.

options.label: C
options.text: By following steps to change the way they perceive smells.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the steps to train the brain to smell better?
Why should people bring their nose close to the world around them?

options.label: C
options.text: To make the smell easier to smell.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the smell more pleasant.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when we sniff?

options.label: A
options.text: Odor molecules are released into the air.

options.label: B
options.text: Odor molecules are sucked up into our nostrils until they hit the olfactory epithelium.

options.label: C
options.text: Odor molecules are absorbed into the bloodstream.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when an odor molecule binds to a scent receptor?

options.label: A
options.text: It sends a signal to the brain that it is a pleasant smell.

options.label: B
options.text: It sends an electrical signal from the sensory neurons to our brain's olfactory bulbs.

options.label: C
options.text: It releases a hormone that makes us feel happy.

multiple-choice.question: How can people begin to appreciate nuances in familiar odors and recognize characteristics of new and unusual smells?

options.label: B
options.text: By following steps to change the way they perceive smells.

options.label: C
options.text: By taking ingredients from their kitchen and sniffing them.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of an unspectacular action that can change how people sense and experience their days?

options.label: C
options.text: A change in their perception of smells.

title: What I learned from 100 days of rejection - Jia Jiang

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To have them come to the front of the classroom and compliment each other after receiving gifts.

options.label: D

options.text: Because he was scared of being rejected.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he felt embarrassed and his heart was pounding.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he thought he was going to get in trouble.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he was worried about getting a bad grade.

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's goal when he started his 100-day rejection challenge?

options.label: B
options.text: To learn how to overcome his fear of rejection.

multiple-choice.question: What was the magic word that the speaker found could turn a "no" into a "yes"?
What did the speaker learn from his experience of asking the stranger if he could plant a flower in his backyard?

options.label: A
options.text: That the stranger was a kind person.

options.label: B
options.text: That the stranger had a dog that would dig up anything.

options.label: C
options.text: That the speaker could turn a "no" into a "yes" by asking "why".

options.label: D
options.text: That the speaker should not have asked the stranger.

options.label: B
options.text: That the manager was hesitant at first but then agreed.

options.label: C

options.text: That being a greeter is a boring job.

options.label: A
options.text: Martin Luther King, Jr., Mahatma Gandhi, Nelson Mandela, and Jesus Christ.

options.label: C
options.text: The people who attended the speaker's talk.

options.label: D
options.text: The people who read the speaker's book.

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker use to help people overcome their fear of rejection?

options.label: C
options.text: Consider the possibilities and don't run.

title: What does this symbol actually mean? - Adrian Treharne

multiple-choice.question: What is the formal title of the International Symbol of Access as maintained by the ISO?
